intro: Habrothamnus roseus, commonly known as the pink sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves and showy, pinkish-red flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. It has a low, spreading growth habit and produces small, bead-like fruits that contain seeds. Due to its unique appearance and ecological adaptations, it is often found in desert landscapes and is of interest to botanists and horticulturists.
